Description: Fragment from neck from a rhyton, or a closed vase. Decoration- turquoise blue-green glaze inside and outside. Outside decoration - plain area running up to out-turned lip, below, beneath a narrow horizontal ridge, a low relief decoration of egg and dart,then a narrow plain band, with low relief wave-like running scroll below, and zone with griffins or sphinx(?) like figures and floral ornaments.Upturned wing and head of animal anticlockwise with central tree in front. Three pieces (88.853a-d) joined together, though one is made up of two fragments so it is really four. Fifth fragment E is a body fragment (from lower part of) of globular shape, glazed inside and out; it may belong but this is not sure. Low relief decoration on the outside at bottom with calix of lotus sepal carefully modelled with ribs done with raised lines; above, incised running scroll in form of vine tendrils with three lobed leaves.Above another frieze with leaf elements ? Dimensions: Diam of neck at ridge above egg and dart ca. 9.6cm. Dimensions of fr.E: 5x6cm.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels dated to the 3rd century BC include restricted vases (Nenna and Seif el-Din, 2000, Form T7.1; Nenna 2013, Fig. 6.5, T7.1a, see also 7.1b and c). However, the closest parallels are for rhytons also dated to the 3rd century BC (Nenna and Seif el-Din, 2000, Form T6.3, Pl. 45, no. 264 and 269; Nenna 2013, Fig. 6.5, T6.3). Nenna, M.-D. 2013. Faience vessels and objects in Nicholson, P. T. (ed.) Working in Memphis: The production of faience at Roman period Kom Helul. London: Egypt Exploration Society: 106-132. Nenna, M.-D. and M. Seif el-Din. La vaisselle en faïece d’époque gréco- romaine. Études Alexandrines 4. Cairo: IFAO.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (FC.06)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5754 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
